awd_titl_txt: Using systematic computational approaches to elucidate the molecular and network dynamics underlying a circadian clock
awd_abstract_narration:
Circadian clocks govern the daily rhythms of organisms across the kingdoms of life, and clock defects can impact the health of both individuals and ecosystems.  This project uses computational models tied closely to biochemical experiments to better understand how circadian clocks work at the molecular level.  Pursuit of this research objective will contribute to interdisciplinary training of graduate and undergraduate students. This, in turn, will enable efforts to expose younger students to STEM topics:  continuation of a highly successful program that places high school juniors in laboratories at the University of Chicago for summer research and the update of a course for Illinois public school teachers that presents inexpensive, hands-on ways of engaging their students and helping them understand the physical laws underlying biology.

Remarkably, the core circadian clock of cyanobacteria can be reconstituted in a test tube.  This permits well-controlled studies that can be used to tease apart complex behaviors and connect clock function with specific molecular events.  By leveraging this system and recent advances in computational methods, major outstanding questions about the clock will be addressed:  Does the slow switch of a participating protein’s fold set the timing of the clock?  How is information communicated between the part of the clock that encodes the time of day and the motor that keeps it advancing steadily forward?  How does the clock maintain a near-24-hour period across conditions that can lead to dramatic changes in elementary reaction rates (i.e., what makes the clock so robust)?

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Circadian clocks govern the daily rhythms of organisms across the kingdoms of life, and clock defects can impact the health of both individuals and ecosystems.  This project used computational models tied closely to biochemical experiments to understand how circadian clocks work at the molecular level.  Specifically, we studied the core biochemical oscillator of the circadian clock of cyanobacteria.  Remarkably, the function of this system can be reconstituted in a test tube, which permits well-controlled studies that can be used to tease apart complex behaviors and connect oscillator function with specific molecular events.

We used a statistical framework for objectively evaluating models for their ability to fit kinetic data to understand how the oscillator maintains its period as the concentration of its fuel (the molecule ATP) is varied.  We discovered computationally and experimentally that the system exhibits a threshold response to the concentration of one of the clock components (KaiA) and models that included this behavior predicted oscillations over a broader range of conditions than models that did not. We also used models together with quantitative measurements to characterize other prokaryotic systems and refined our understanding of how these systems can tune their dynamics in response to stressful conditions.

Proteins are synthesized as linear chains of amino acids, and it was traditionally believed that they must adopt unique three-dimensional folds to function.  Over the past couple decades, this one-sequence/one-fold paradigm broke down.  KaiB is one of the most well-characterized examples of proteins that switch between two folds to perform their functions (known as metamorphic proteins).  We used the statistical framework to show how a previously uncharacterized protein (KidA) newly discovered to interact with KaiB and more generally the clock could tune the period of the clock by regulating the equilibrium between KaiB folds.  Then, we used state-of-the-art simulation methods to elucidate the pathways for fold switching at near-atomic resolution.  These studies provided detailed information about the amino acids that control fold switching and provided insights into how temperature shifts the equilibrium between KaiB folds and in turn how the oscillator maintains its period as temperature changes. 

With a view toward treating more complicated models of the oscillator, we developed a computational approach that dramatically accelerated the evaluation of models with respect to their ability to fit data.  This approach enables firmer statistical conclusions to be drawn and opens the door to integrating diverse biochemical and biophysical measurements.

The intellectual merit of this research was that it showed how proteins and their networks of interactions can function robustly across a wide range of conditions.  The project had many broader impacts.  It advanced our overall knowledge of circadian biology and prokaryotic biology.  It provided training opportunities for graduate, undergraduate, and high school students.  It enabled a collaboration with a historian of science studying the emergence of the concept of biofilms and in turn development of general software for extracting images from scanned scientific articles. The image-extraction software can enable systematic studies of how images reflect and drive scientific discoveries.  The data-fitting software can be used across disciplines.
